Award.AwardTitle: Ion-paired cooperative catalysts for carbon-carbon bond formation
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Catalysis program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Graham Dobereiner of Temple University is developing methods for using carbon monoxide (CO) in the preparation of important chemicals. Carbon monoxide is widely used as a feedstock in the chemical industry for the formation of commodity chemicals. Because its use is so ubiquitous, there is significant value in finding new approaches to using CO that are more efficient than those now used. In this project a new type of catalyst, where two separate parts work together in making chemical bonds, is being developed in order to reduce energy input and decrease resource consumption relative to traditional methods. The investigation includes a sustained outreach program with local schools, as well as readying students for the STEM workforce by organizing regional meetings for future scientists with interests in inorganic chemistry.

In this project, a general approach to preparing ion paired complexes composed of two oppositely charged metal complexes is being developed. The purpose is to provide a library of tunable bimetallic catalysts and to establish the conditions required for preparing stable bimetallic ion pair catalysts. Using this library, catalysts are being designed for several catalytic reactions, including hydroesterification and the selective copolymerization of carbon monoxide and alkenes. Besides yielding efficient catalytic processes, potential benefits include an improved fundamental understanding of ion pairing as well as advancements in the inorganic synthesis.

Institution.Name: Temple University
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: TEMPLE UNIVERSITY-OF THE COMMONWEALTH SYSTEM OF HIGHER EDUCATION

POR.DRECONTENT:
This completed project sought to understand the interactions between cations and anions in homogeneous organometallic reactions relevant to drug development and industrial chemistry.

To better understand how solution species change and behave during chemical reactions, the project team designed charged inorganic and organometallic species, completed the synthesis of novel weakly coordinating anions, and the elucidated of the mechanism of additive effects in homogeneous catalytic reactions. 

 

Resulting major publications:

Becica, J.; Dobereiner, G.E. Acceleration of Pd-catalyzed amide N-arylations using co-catalytic metal triflates: Substrate scope and mechanistic study. ACS Catalysis, 2017, 7, 5862-5870.

The team explored the substrate scope of a metal triflate-accelerated N-arylation of amides catalyzed by palladium complexes, and performed a mechanistic study to elucidate the origin of the accelerating effect. The metal triflates appear to facilitate exchange of Pd halide for an amide ligand (so-called "transmetalation"), presumably by Lewis acid abstraction of halide.

 

Wozniak, D.I.; Sabbers, W.A.; Weerasiri, K.C.; Dinh, L.V.; Quenzer, J.L.; Hicks, A.J.; Dobereiner, G.E. Comparing interactions of a three-coordinate Pd cation with common weakly-coordinating anions. Organometallics, 2018, 37, 2376-2385.

To build the groundwork for cooperative bimetallic reactions via ion pairing, the team completed a systematic measurement of relative coordinating ability of common anions. The study provides straightforward spectroscopic and computational approaches to estimating the extent of inner-sphere association both in the solid state and in solution, and will be of use for controlling relatively-weak cation/anion interactions for productive catalysis.

 

Becica, J.; Hruszkewycz, D.P.; Steves, J.E.; Elward, J.M.; Leitch, D.C.; Dobereiner, G.E. High-Throughput Discovery and Evaluation of a General Catalytic Method for N-Arylation of Weakly Nucleophilic Sulfonamides. Organic Letters, 2019, 21, 8981-8986.

Graduate student Joseph Becica completed a three-month internship at GlaxoSmithKline (GSK) supported via an Improving Graduate Student Preparedness supplement to this award. GSK high throughput screening (HTS) tools offered the team a trove of data to use in developing guiding principles for rational Pd catalysis design. The priority was to identify improved catalytic conditions for producing tertiary N-aryl sulfonamides - widespread in pharmaceutical scaffolds yet challenging to prepare using existing Pd methods. The project team identified general conditions for  N-arylation of secondary sulfonamides, demonstrating coupling of more than 100 sulfonamide and aryl halide substrate combinations.

 

Wozniak, D.I.; Hicks, A.J.; Sabbers, W.A.; Dobereiner, G.E. Imidazolyl-Phenyl (IMP) Anions: A Modular Structure for Tuning Solubility and Coordinating Ability. Dalton Transactions, 2019, 48, 14138-14155

The project team sought an anion platform that allows fine-tuning of coordinating ability and solubility. They developed the IMP anion class and explored its synthetic and catalytic applications. The team demonstrated directly how the anions can be used in both fundamental (mechanism) and applied (optimization) efforts in organometallic chemistry, including Pd and Au catalysis. The IMP anions are straightforward to prepare, very robust, and easily modified.

 

Broader Impacts:

The catalyst techniques recently developed will make an immediate impact by facilitating the N-arylation of amides, of interest to pharmaceutical companies in their efforts to discover new drug candidates. The procedures discovered for preparing novel gold and copper complexes will be of value to other chemists striving to construct novel catalyst architectures and luminescent organometallic species for OLED applications.

The award has also directly supported the professional development of the PI and graduate student research assistants by allowing participation in national conferences in the field, supported their outreach efforts, and provided resources for the professional development of a student during an industrial internship at a pharmaceutical company.

 


Last Modified: 12/29/2020
Modified by: Graham E Dobereiner
